conclusion: To determine when the two cars collide, we need to analyze the v-t graph provided for both cars, Car A and Car B.
The graph shows velocity (v) on the y-axis and time (t) on the x-axis.
Car A starts at a velocity of 25 m/s and Car B starts at a velocity of 15 m/s.
Both cars are decelerating, as indicated by the downward sloping lines.
Car A's line is steeper than Car B's, indicating that Car A is decelerating faster than Car B.
The collision occurs when both cars have the same velocity at the same time, meaning their lines intersect on the graph.
The intersection point on the graph is marked by a red dot.
This intersection occurs slightly before the 20-second mark on the time axis.
Since the intersection point (collision) occurs before the 20-second mark, the two cars collide before 20 seconds of braking.
The two cars collide before 20 seconds of braking.
